citations.narrative:
Eight Labradoodle puppies were in an enclosure that measured 49 inches by 73 inches for a total floor space of 3,577
square inches. The puppies measured 16 inches, 17 inches, 17 inches, 17.5 inches, 17.5 inches, 18 inches, 19 inches,
and 21 inches. The eight puppies required 4,576.5 square inches of space so the enclosure was short by 999.5 square
inches of space.
Cage space requirements ensure that the dogs have enough room to move about freely within their enclosures. It
minimizes the dogs from stepping or sitting in their feces or urine and also minimizes the spread of disease. The licensee
must ensure that all enclosures containing dogs and puppies have enough floor space to meet the minimum floor space
requirements for the number of and the size of the dogs in that enclosure.
Correct starting on 7/19/23.

The licensee has an exercise plan, but it has not been approved by the Attending Veterinarian. Not having the exercise
plan approved by the Attending Veterinarian doesn't ensure the licensee is providing the dogs with adequate exercise
opportunities. The licensee must have the Attending Veterinarian approve of the exercise plan. Correct by 8/19/23.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
During inspection, a strong ammonia smell was observed in multiple areas of the kennel including a dog house in an
outdoor enclosure, puppy building on the northeast part of the dog kennel, the room on the southwest part of the kennel
next to the outdoor enclosures, and a room on the northwest part of the kennel that was housing two adult dogs.
Ammonia buildup indicates the enclosures aren't being cleaned or sanitized as often as necessary. Ammonia build up can
also be a health hazard to the dogs and anyone working in the kennel. All buildings and rooms housing dogs must be
sanitized as often as necessary to prevent disease or health hazards from becoming a problem. Correct by 7/26/23.

The program of veterinary care doesn't have how many or what percentage of dogs have to be heartworm tested and
fecal tested. The licensee has ten dogs that have been heartworm tested and fecal tested within the past year, but not
having the Attending Veterinarian add how many dogs need to be heartworm tested and fecal tested into the program of
veterinary care doesn't ensure that an adequate number of dogs have been tested. The licensee must have the Attending
Veterinarian add how many dogs are required to be heartworm tested and fecal tested every year.
Correct by 8/19/23.

Three adult dogs were matted up around their ears and necks. Matted hair coats on dogs can be painful for the dogs, can
cause skin infections and skin irritation, and can prevent the licensee from being able to properly observe the dogs skin
underneath the mats. All dogs must be properly groomed to prevent matting. Correct by 7/26/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End of report.
n

narrative:
3.6(c)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Eight Labradoodle puppies were in an enclosure that measured 49 inches by 73 inches for a total floor space of 3,577 
square inches. The puppies measured 16 inches, 17 inches, 17 inches, 17.5 inches, 17.5 inches, 18 inches, 19 inches, 
and 21 inches. The eight puppies required 4,576.5 square inches of space so the enclosure was short by 999.5 square 
inches of space. 
 
Cage space requirements ensure that the dogs have enough room to move about freely within their enclosures. It 
minimizes the dogs from stepping or sitting in their feces or urine and also minimizes the spread of disease. The licensee 
must ensure that all enclosures containing dogs and puppies have enough floor space to meet the minimum floor space 
requirements for the number of and the size of the dogs in that enclosure. 
 
Correct starting on 7/19/23. 
3.8 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
The licensee has an exercise plan, but it has not been approved by the Attending Veterinarian. Not having the exercise 
plan approved by the Attending Veterinarian doesn't ensure the licensee is providing the dogs with adequate exercise 
opportunities. The licensee must have the Attending Veterinarian approve of the exercise plan. Correct by 8/19/23. 
3.11(b)(2) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
During inspection, a strong ammonia smell was observed in multiple areas of the kennel including a dog house in an 
outdoor enclosure, puppy building on the northeast part of the dog kennel, the room on the southwest part of the kennel 
next to the outdoor enclosures, and a room on the northwest part of the kennel that was housing two adult dogs. 
Ammonia buildup indicates the enclosures aren't being cleaned or sanitized as often as necessary. Ammonia build up can 
also be a health hazard to the dogs and anyone working in the kennel. All buildings and rooms housing dogs must be 
sanitized as often as necessary to prevent disease or health hazards from becoming a problem. Correct by 7/26/23. 
3.13(a)(3)

Veterinary care for dogs. 
The program of veterinary care doesn't have how many or what percentage of dogs have to be heartworm tested and 
fecal tested. The licensee has ten dogs that have been heartworm tested and fecal tested within the past year, but not 
having the Attending Veterinarian add how many dogs need to be heartworm tested and fecal tested into the program of 
veterinary care doesn't ensure that an adequate number of dogs have been tested. The licensee must have the Attending 
Veterinarian add how many dogs are required to be heartworm tested and fecal tested every year. 
 
Correct by 8/19/23. 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
Three adult dogs were matted up around their ears and necks. Matted hair coats on dogs can be painful for the dogs, can 
cause skin infections and skin irritation, and can prevent the licensee from being able to properly observe the dogs skin 
underneath the mats. All dogs must be properly groomed to prevent matting. Correct by 7/26/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
End of report.
